item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: February 7
item.description: Shiva Keshavan of India training in Sochi, Russia ahead of the Sochi 2014 Winter Olympics.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Shiva Keshavan of India in the Luge during a training session ahead of the Sochi 2014 Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia.

item.title: Syriaâ€™s Government Says It Will Stay in Peace Talks as U.N.-Brokered Homs Evacuation Begins
item.description: Civilians who had been trapped in the Old City neighborhood of Homs began to leave under an agreement negotiated by the United Nations.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD and RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: A rebel fighter sat amid the rubble of damaged buildings inÂ eastern Syria on Thursday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Supporters Call for Investigation into Death of Chinese Activistâ€™s Father
item.description: The authorities in Shandong Province told family members that Xue Fushun committed suicide by jumping from the fourth story of a procuratorâ€™s office building in the city of Qufu.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Xue Mingkai, whose father, Xue Fushun, died under disputed circumstances.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Stranded Travelers Start â€˜Riotâ€™ at Airport
item.description: Flight delays caused by days of heavy snowfall came at the peak travel season for China, when billions of journeys are made over 40 days around the Lunar New Year holiday.
item.category: Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG
item.media:description: Passengers rest on luggage carts on Friday after being stranded because of heavy snowfall at the Zhengzhou Xinzheng International Airport. Frustrated travelers smashed airport equipment late Wednesday and Thursday, the end of the week-long Lunar New Year holiday, as millions tried to return to work.

item.title: U.S. Diplomatâ€™s Remark on European Union â€˜Unacceptable,â€™ Merkel Says
item.description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany on Friday criticized an assistant secretary of stateâ€™s undiplomatic comment on European efforts to resolve the political crisis in Ukraine.
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE
item.media:credit: John Macdougall/Agence France-Presse â€” Getty Images
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany issued a sharp statement denouncing the American diplomat's remarks on the political crisis in Kiev.

item.title: India Ink: Desperate for Clean Air, Delhi Residents Experiment with Solutions
item.description: Air purifiers, indoor plants and masks are just some of the ways people in the Indian capital have tried to keep pollution out of their lungs.
item.dc:creator: By MAX BEARAK
item.media:description: Smog and fog enveloping Rajpath, a ceremonial boulevard, in New Delhi on Wednesday.

item.title: U.S. Issues Penalties Over Violations of Iran Sanctions
item.description: Nearly three dozen companies and individuals were accused of evading the economic measures â€” an indication that the United States was not relaxing its pressure despite a temporary nuclear agreement.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Amid Raft of Chinese Financial Numbers, One to Watch Carefully
item.description: China Development Bank, which lends billions for infrastructure projects, has seen its own borrowing costs soar by about 50 percent, adding to the debate over whether the country can defy pessimists and continue to outgrow its neighbors
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: Cameron Urges Scots to Remain in United Kingdom
item.description: The British prime minister appealed to Scottish voters to reject independence in a referendum that will be held in September.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Petition to Nullify Thai Election Is Rejected in Setback for Opposition
item.description: Days after the election, there are contradictory signals about which side has the upper hand in Thailandâ€™s debilitating power struggle.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER

item.title: Indonesia Grants Parole to Australian Woman in Drug Case
item.description: The 20-year sentence given to Schapelle Corby for bringing marijuana to Bali angered many Australians and caused a diplomatic row with Canberra.
item.dc:creator: By JOE COCHRANE

item.title: India Ink: A Homegrown Comic Con Highlights Growth in Local Comics Market
item.description: Attendance at these fan conventions has grown over the past three years, and publishers have taken notice.
item.dc:creator: By SATYA KANDALA
item.media:description: People dressed as superheroes taking part in a contest at a 2-day Comic Con festival in Mumbai, Maharashtra, on Dec. 21, 2013.Â

item.title: Report Says North Korea Is Improving Missile Capabilities
item.description: By expanding its main satellite launch site, North Korea may be able to accommodate larger rockets for its ballistic missile program.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Ban on Liquids for Carry-Ons on Direct U.S.-Russia Flights
item.description: No liquids, gels, aerosols or powders will be allowed in carry-on bags on nonstop flights between the United States and Russia during the Winter Olympics in Sochi.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: In Hong Kong, an Unexploded Bomb Forces Evacuations
item.description: Unexploded World War II bombs are an occasional fact of life in the prosperous and crowded city.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY

item.title: Vasil Bilak, Czechoslovak Communist Who Encouraged 1968 Soviet Invasion, Dies at 96
item.description: Mr. Bilak was a former hard-line communist leader who paved the way for Soviet invasion of Czechoslovakia in 1968.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Environmental Groups Denounce Arrests of Ecologists Near Olympic Sites
item.description: Arrests of two ecologists in Sochi, Russia, have alarmed environmental groups, which criticized the stringent controls that authorities have placed on public shows of dissent near Olympic sites.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: Mikhail Mordasov/Agence France-Presse â€” Getty Images
item.media:description: A view of Olympic Park in December. Dump sites for construction debris litter hills in and around Sochi, Russia. Other such damage has been well documented.

item.title: Amid Flow of Leaks, Turkey Moves to Crimp Internet
item.description: Many in Turkey see the new laws as an effort to stem leaks in a corruption investigation of the prime minister and those close to him.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO and CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.media:description: Many in Turkey see the laws as a government effort to stem leaks in a corruption investigation.

item.title: The Lede: Defenders of SodaStream Confuse Boycotts of Israeli Settlements With Movement to Boycott Israel
item.description: The antipoverty group Oxfam rejected claims that it has called for a boycott of Israel.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Brain-Dead, a Canadian Woman Remains a Silent Partner Awaiting Birth
item.description: The family of Robyn Benson, who sustained a fatal brain hemorrhage, hopes her fetus will mature enough to be delivered.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN
item.media:description: Dylan and Robyn Benson on their wedding day last year. She has been kept on life support.

item.title: Russia Claims U.S. Meddling Over Ukraine
item.description: Meanwhile, the Obama administration blamed Moscow for spreading an intercepted private conversation between two American diplomats.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS and PETER BAKER
item.media:description: Dmytro Bulatov, a protest leader, spoke Thursday about being kidnapped.

item.title: In Royal Drama, Spain Sees Its Reality Reflected
item.description: The legal scandal involving Princess Cristina and her husband over money laundering has become a morality tale of excess whose themes are common enough in a country where the receding economic tide after 2008 exposed corruption and mismanagement.
item.dc:creator: By DOREEN CARVAJAL and SILVIA TAULÃ‰S
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.media:description: The finances of Princess Cristina, with bodyguards, and her husband are under investigation.

item.title: Syrian City to Receive Aid, Officials Say
item.description: A small step by the Syrian government to ease the plight of civilians in Homs is met with cautious optimism.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Guatemala Court Rules to Curb Crusader
item.description: The countryâ€™s highest court ruled that the crusading attorney general, Claudia Paz y Paz, must step down in May, seven months before her four-year term was to end.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETH MALKIN
